title: ‘Barangays should lead drug war’
text:
‘Barangays should lead drug war’ By Emmanuel Tupas (The Philippine Star)   
MANILA, Philippines - Barangay officials should get more involved in the government’s war against drugs, according to the Philippine Drug Enforcement Agency. 
PDEA director general Isidro Lapeña said yesterday that barangays should lead the anti-drug campaign at the grassroots level, as he renewed his call for the creation of anti-drug abuse councils. 
“It is imperative that every barangay must have an anti-drug abuse council,” Lapeña said, citing a memorandum issued by the Department of the Interior and Local Government. 
The DILG memorandum stressed the importance of the barangay anti-drug abuse councils or BADACs in the government’s war against drugs and in drug-clearing operations. 
Some barangays do not have a BADAC or an anti-drug program for their constituents, which Lapeña said is a violation of the law. 
Under the DILG memorandum, failure of local officials to appropriate a portion of their budgets to assist or enhance Republic Act 9165 or the Comprehensive Dangerous Drugs Act of 2002 is a ground for disapproval of a barangay’s annual budget.   
The law also provides that administrative cases for dereliction of duty await violators. 
“A local official found engaging in the manufacture, sale, delivery, transport and use of illegal drugs will be dealt with criminally and administratively pursuant to the anti-drug law,” said Lapeña. 
“BADACs is important in maintaining a pro-active stand in shielding the ordinary people from the drug menace. A barangay is considered to be the smallest administrative unit in the Philippines.” 
Lapeña said the battle against drug abuse and trafficking at the community and street level begins in the barangays, however small in structure. 
The BADAC must be composed of the barangay chairman as head and a barangay kagawad as vice chair. 
The members are composed of a Sangguniang Kabataan chairman, school principal and representatives from non-governmental organizations, parents-teachers’ association and religious group. 
President Duterte tasked the PDEA to lead the drug war after he stripped the Philippine National Police (PNP) and the National Bureau of Investigation (NBI) of the power to conduct anti-drug operations. 
The suspension of Oplan Tokhang was due to the killing of South Korean businessman Jee Ick-joo allegedly by police officers and NBI agents. 3 drug suspects arrested 
Three drug suspects were arrested in separate anti-drug operations in Ilocos Sur, Occidental Mindoro and Sorsogon, on Wednesday. 
Lapeña identified the suspects as Ronald Sining, 38; Heron Iñigo, 28, and Lawrence Mariano, 41. 
Sining was arrested by PDEA agents at his residence in Barangay Bitalag, Bacnotan, Sorsogon. 
Authorities said they seized an undetermined amount of shabu and marked money from Sining. 
Iñigo was arrested after he sold P270 worth of shabu to an undercover agent in Barangay San Pedro City, Candon City, Ilocos Sur. 
Mariano yielded P500 worth of shabu following a sting in Barangay San Roque, San Jose City in Occidental Mindoro.
